newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks end down after four days of gains.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks end down after four days of gains.

text.p: Taiwan share prices opened higher but ended with a downturn on Thursday on slack-trade profit taking, ending a string of four straight days of minor gains.
The index ended down 46.69 points or 0.67 percent at 6,889.03 after hitting an intrasession high of 6,952.62.
Turnover was a modest T$38.8 billion.
Brokers attributed the correction mainly to relatively sluggish year-end window-dressing by institutional investors.
"Seeing that the expected window-dressing by institutions did not emerge actively, individual investors turned to take profits first," said Golden Securities manager Albert Lin.
Construction shares, which had risen recently on expected recovery in Taiwan's long-depressed property market, led the falls, with Long Bon Construction down T$1.3 to T$30.9.
The financial sector, another recent gainer, also was weak, with Central Insurance down T$2 to T$67.
Textiles and plastics also fell, but electronics, which had suffered downward corrections recently, rebounded slightly, with Compal Electronics up T$2 to T$61.5.
Closed-end funds rose on hopes that they would issue high cash dividends in February or March 1997, with Jardine Fleming Fund up 25 cents to T$11.55, brokers said.

"Due to the sound performance of Taiwan's stock market in 1996, these closed-end funds are expected each to issue high cash dividends of around T$2 to T$3 per share in February or March 1997," said Nikko Securities research chief Michael Hung.
Brokers said the index's fall below 6,900 was something of a surprise as many had anticipated a firming trend to test the 7,000-point resistance in the final days of 1996 trading.
"I'm not so sure now if the index can make it (breaking the 7,000-point level)," Hung said.
A 6,850-6,910 range was seen for Friday.
